Shape: A large sparrow with a short, conical bill, an elongated body for a sparrow, and a rather long tail. The overall shape is similar to Northern Cardinal (but with a smaller bill and without the crest).
Compared Size: Slightly larger than a Northern Cardinal, smaller than a Woodhouse’s Scrub-Jay.

description: Abert’s Towhee is grayish-brown above, pinkish brown below, with rusty undertail coverts and black plumage bordering a pale grayish bill.

Abert’s Towhees spend most of their time on the ground. They forage mostly beneath dense undergrowth, flying very little during the course of a day, and seldom perch high in trees. Even singing males tend to prefer brush or the lower parts of trees.
Low, dense cover along desert streams and riverbeds with cottonwoods, willows, or mesquite.
